Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from six fragments) of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery lekane with handle root; white slip; interior, from top: broad black band at rim; maeander pattern running left between pairs of lines; painted decoration consisting of hindquarters with added red on rump of a lion walking to left; goat with red squares on rump, body, shoulder and neck, walking to right; pendant roundels and triangle; rising roundel and triangle, elaborate rosettes and swastikas as filling ornament; below, maeander pattern running left between pairs of lines; wide black band with traces of two dot rosettes in added white; on top of rim, outlined alternating black and red tongues; dotted billets on top of handle root; black strokes on inside and outside of rim; on underside of rim, streaky black band; exterior: key maeander pattern running left between lines framing main frieze, consisting of goats grazing to right (horn of first goat; second goat with red squares on rump, body, shoulder and neck); pendant and rising triangle and rosette, swastika and dotted rosette as filling ornament; below, hook maeander frieze. Graffito inscriptions beside handle join and on interior of lip.
Producer name: Attributed to: Group of the Aphrodite Bowl
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ1(?)
Curator's comments: A sherd on the market, May 2019, with part of 'anethhke' preserved below the rim is to be equated with Gardner no. 702 and is probably from the same piece; see A. Johnston, 'Naukratis II 702 and 779 rediviva' Zeitschrift fuer Papyrologie und Epigraphik 213 (2020) 111-2 and 116, fig. 5.
On inside of rim pencil A782 X.

Lemos describes the sherd as part of the Group of the Aphrodite Bowl, rather than as by the painter of the bowl, because the sherd displays a greater amount of variety in the filling ornaments, albeit similar to those on the Aphrodite Bowl (Lemos 1991, 74-5). The sherd most probably belongs to the same vase as UCL 754.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 27, p. 73, p. 243, no. 253, fig. 13, pl. 28)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 26)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2057) (phase 2)
